claim: If duplicate accounts belonging to the same person were automatically merged, the number of adult users with more than 5000 upvotes would increase.
extra_info: adult users refer to Age BETWEEN 19 and 65; over 5000 upvotes refer to UpVotes > 5000;
reasoning: This is a counterfactual claim ('If duplicate accounts were merged...'). It describes a hypothetical scenario about what would happen under an imagined change. The database records actual data, not what would happen under hypothetical account merging. There is no way to verify from the database which accounts belong to the same person or what the effect of merging them would be.

content.text:
This claim describes a hypothetical "what if" scenario: "If duplicate accounts belonging to the same person were automatically merged..." This is a counterfactual claim about what would happen under an imagined change (merging duplicate accounts).

The database records what actually exists — actual user accounts and their actual upvotes. It does not contain information about which accounts belong to the same person, nor can it simulate what would happen if accounts were merged. This is a classic counterfactual that cannot be verified from the data.
